title: Understanding Compound Interest
subtitle: Choose how deep you want to go - from basic concept to advanced applications

content.summary: Compound interest is earning interest on your interest. Unlike simple interest which only calculates on the principal, compound interest grows exponentially because each period's interest is added to the base for the next calculation.

points.text: Your money earns interest, then that interest earns its own interest
points.tooltip: This creates a snowball effect over time

points.text: The longer you leave money invested, the more powerful the effect becomes
points.tooltip: Time is the most important factor in compound growth

points.text: Even small regular contributions can grow to significant amounts
points.tooltip: Consistency beats timing in most cases

content.summary: The compound interest formula is A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt), where P is principal, r is annual rate, n is compounding frequency, and t is time in years.

points.text: More frequent compounding means slightly higher returns
points.tooltip: Daily compounding beats monthly, which beats yearly - but the differences are small

points.text: The Rule of 72: divide 72 by your interest rate to estimate doubling time
points.tooltip: At 6% interest, money doubles roughly every 12 years (72/6=12)

points.text: Small rate differences matter enormously over long periods
points.tooltip: 1% extra over 30 years can mean 30%+ more money

content.summary: Understanding compound interest transforms how you approach saving, investing, and debt. It explains why starting early matters so much and why high-interest debt is so dangerous.

points.text: A 25-year-old investing $200/month will beat a 35-year-old investing $400/month at retirement
points.tooltip: Those extra 10 years of compounding outweigh doubling the contribution

points.text: Credit card debt compounds against you - 20% APR doubles debt in under 4 years
points.tooltip: Pay off high-interest debt before investing

points.text: Tax-advantaged accounts amplify compound growth by not reducing the base
points.tooltip: Taxes on gains reduce your compounding base - deferring them lets more compound

content.summary: True mastery means optimizing every lever: contribution amounts, timing, tax efficiency, fee minimization, and reinvestment strategy. Small optimizations compound dramatically over decades.

points.text: Fee drag: a 1% annual fee can cost you 25% of your final balance over 30 years
points.tooltip: Choose low-cost index funds - fees compound negatively

points.text: Dollar-cost averaging reduces timing risk while maintaining compound benefits
points.tooltip: Regular investing beats trying to time the market

points.text: Dividend reinvestment accelerates compounding without additional contributions
points.tooltip: DRIP programs automatically reinvest dividends for you
